title: Analyze a grid of Td and Ed values
text: function snvec() uses parameters full astronomical solution () ZB18a Zeebe Lourens (2019) combination values tidal dissipation (Td) dynamical ellipticity (Ed) calculate precession obliquity (tilt). vignette show go using snvec() range input values.

what: Create a grid of Td and Ed
title: Analyze a grid of Td and Ed values
text: create grid input values Td Ed. values grid based Zeebe Lourens (2022) table 2. now add columns important parameter values vary experiments, clear output inputs .
code: biggrid <- as_tibble(   expand.grid(Td = c(0, 0.5, 0.7, 0.8, 0.9, 1.0, 1.1, 1.2),               Ed = c(1.000, 0.998, 1.005, 1.012))) # that's 32 rows biggrid #> # A tibble: 32 × 2 #>       Td    Ed #>    <dbl> <dbl> #>  1   0   1     #>  2   0.5 1     #>  3   0.7 1     #>  4   0.8 1     #>  5   0.9 1     #>  6   1   1     #>  7   1.1 1     #>  8   1.2 1     #>  9   0   0.998 #> 10   0.5 0.998 #> # ℹ 22 more rows biggrid <- biggrid |>     # for now only for 1000 years at very high tolerance so it's fast     mutate(atol = 1e-4, tend = -1e3)     # this would be the real deal, the full 100--0 Myr results at medium     # tolerance.     ## mutate(tol = 1e-7, tend = -1e5)

what: Calculate a new list-column with the results
title: Analyze a grid of Td and Ed values
text: ’re going use purrr::pmap() , allows apply function given list input values. use create list-column results. advanced R stuff, feel free read want Wickham et al., (2023). particular, see chapter iteration basics, many models full approach. apply snvec() function directly full 100 Myr, quickly make R run memory, storing timesteps 32 experiments. Instead, write wrapper function stores latest N timesteps. Compute obliquity precession parameter combination, save new list-column sol. read old results (9MB -disk final 1000 timesteps full 100 Myr simulations).
code: snvec_tail <- function(..., n = 100) {   # do the fit with the parameters in ...   snvec(...) |>     # save only the last n values, that's where the differences are greatest     tail(n = n) } biggrid <- biggrid |>     # apply our new function!     mutate(sol = pmap(list(td = Td, ed = Ed, tend = tend, atol = atol),                       .f = snvec_tail,                       # additional parameters to snvec_tail can go after!                       quiet = TRUE, output = "nice", n = 100,                       # I would strongly recommend against increasing the                       # resolution too much, but for speed/illustration we                       # prefer to do it here                       tres = -5,                       # interactively this makes a nice progress bar                       .progress = "snvec on a grid")) #|> #> snvec on a grid ■■                                 3% |  ETA:  5m #> snvec on a grid ■■■                                6% |  ETA:  3m #> snvec on a grid ■■■■■■■■                          22% |  ETA: 48s #> snvec on a grid ■■■■■■■■■■■■■                     41% |  ETA: 25s #> snvec on a grid ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■                56% |  ETA: 15s #> snvec on a grid ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■           72% |  ETA:  9s #> snvec on a grid ■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■■       88% |  ETA:  4s      # normally we would save the results to file, because these take quite a     # long time to calculate and we don't want to accidentally delete them.     ## write_rds("out/2023-04-05_biggrid.rds") biggrid <- readr::read_rds("out/2023-04-05_biggrid.rds")

title: Analyze a grid of Td and Ed values
text: Let’s look structure output: can see list column sol result! ’d like access raw output, use unnest(). Let’s make figure final values.  Now analysis can begin!

what: Alternatively: save the results for each row to file instead
title: Analyze a grid of Td and Ed values
text: care full outputs simulations, approach likely make run memory (crash R). One way deal write simulation file. create filename variables use purrr::pwalk() stead pmap(). look like : write new wrapper function includes file argument save outputs. Calculate time series’ obliquity precession save file. lead creation one file per row, can read individually certain subset using readr::read_rds(). files make plot!
code: biggrid <- biggrid |>   # get rid of sol column   select(-sol) |>   # add a filename that's easy to break into relevant parameters later   # I write to tempdir here, but you might want to write to something like out/   mutate(file = glue::glue("{tempdir()}/2023-04-13_biggrid_{Td}_{Ed}_{atol}_{tend}.rds")) biggrid #> # A tibble: 32 × 5 #>       Td    Ed   atol  tend file                                                 #>    <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <glue>                                               #>  1   0   1     0.0001 -1000 /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0_1_1e-04_-1000.… #>  2   0.5 1     0.0001 -1000 /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0.5_1_1e-04_-100… #>  3   0.7 1     0.0001 -1000 /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0.7_1_1e-04_-100… #>  4   0.8 1     0.0001 -1000 /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0.8_1_1e-04_-100… #>  5   0.9 1     0.0001 -1000 /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0.9_1_1e-04_-100… #>  6   1   1     0.0001 -1000 /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_1_1_1e-04_-1000.… #>  7   1.1 1     0.0001 -1000 /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_1.1_1_1e-04_-100… #>  8   1.2 1     0.0001 -1000 /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_1.2_1_1e-04_-100… #>  9   0   0.998 0.0001 -1000 /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0_0.998_1e-04_-1… #> 10   0.5 0.998 0.0001 -1000 /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0.5_0.998_1e-04_… #> # ℹ 22 more rows snvec_save <- function(..., file) {   snvec(...) |>     readr::write_rds(file)   cli::cli_inform("Wrote file {.file {file}}.") } biggrid |>   # in this case we make sure that column names are identical to argument names   # so that the list (in this case tibble/data.frame) is matched to the correct   # arguments   rename(td = Td, ed = Ed, atol = atol) |>   purrr::pwalk(.f = snvec_save,                # additional parameters can go after!                quiet = TRUE, output = "nice", tres = -5,                # show progress bar                .progress = "snvec to file") #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0_1_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0.5_1_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0.7_1_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> snvec to file ■■■■                               9% |  ETA: 17s #>  #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0.8_1_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0.9_1_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_1_1_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_1.1_1_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_1.2_1_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> snvec to file ■■■■■■■■■                         25% |  ETA: 14s #>  #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0_0.998_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0.5_0.998_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0.7_0.998_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0.8_0.998_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_0.9_0.998_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> snvec to file ■■■■■■■■■■■■■                     41% |  ETA: 11s #>  #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_1_0.998_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_1.1_0.998_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_1.1_1.012_1e-04_-1000.rds. #> Wrote file /tmp/Rtmpt58qUr/2023-04-13_biggrid_1.2_1.012_1e-04_-1000.rds. biggrid |> # limit to a few experiments   ## slice(c(1, 15, 32)) |>   # in this case that's not necessary because we limited it to a very   # low-resolution (tres) and short time period (tend)   # read them in to list-column   mutate(fullsol = map(file, readr::read_rds)) |>   # unfold the list column   unnest(fullsol) |>   # plot the obliquity   ggplot(aes(x = time, y = epl,              colour = factor(Td),              linetype = factor(Ed))) +   labs(x = "Time (kyr)", y = "Obliquity",        colour = "Tidal dissipation",        linetype = "Dynamical ellipticity") +   ## facet_grid(rows = vars(Td)) +   geom_line()

title: Authors and Citation
text: Ilja Kocken. Author, maintainer, translator, copyright holder. Richard Zeebe. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Kocken , Zeebe R (2023). snvecR: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity Precession Past. doi:10.5281/zenodo.7865279, https://japhir.github.io/snvecR/.
code: @Manual{KockenZeebe2023,   title = {snvecR: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past},   author = {Ilja Kocken and Richard Zeebe},   year = {2023},   abstract = {Easily calculate precession and obliquity from an astronomical solution (defaults to ZB18a from Zeebe and Lourens (2019)) and assumed or reconstructed values for tidal dissipation (Td) and dynamical ellipticity (Ed). This is a translation and adaptation of the C-code in the supplementary material to Zeebe and Lourens (2022), with further details on the methodology described in Zeebe (2022). The name of the C-routine is snvec, which refers to the key units of computation: spin vector s and orbit normal vector n.},   version = {3.9.1},   doi = {10.5281/zenodo.7865279},   url = {https://japhir.github.io/snvecR/}, }

what: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past
title: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past
text: Easily calculate precession obliquity astronomical solution (, defaults ZB18a Zeebe Lourens (2019)) assumed reconstructed values tidal dissipation (Td) dynamical ellipticity (Ed). translation adaptation C-code supplementary material Zeebe Lourens (2022), details methodology described Zeebe (2022). name C-routine snvec, refers key units computation: spin vector s orbit normal vector n.

title: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past
text: can install snvecR like : use development version package, use:

title: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past
text: ’s main function work action: see ?snvec documentation. create quick plot calculated climatic precession eccentricity envelope:
code: library(snvecR) solution <- snvec() #> ℹ The astronomical solution full-ZB18a has not been downloaded. #> ℹ Reading 'full-ZB18a.dat' from website <http://www.soest.hawaii.edu/oceanography/faculty/zeebe_files/Astro/PrecTilt/OS/ZB18a/ems-plan3.dat>. #> ℹ Calculating helper columns. #> ℹ The cache directory is '/home/japhir/.cache/R/snvecR'. #> ℹ Saved 'full-ZB18a.dat' to cache. #> ℹ Saved cleaned-up 'full-ZB18a.csv' to cache. #> → Saved solution with helper columns 'full-ZB18a.rds' to cache. #> This is snvecR VERSION: 3.9.0 2024-02-29 #> Richard E. Zeebe #> Ilja J. Kocken #>  #> Integration parameters: #> • `tend` = -1000 kyr #> • `ed` = 1 #> • `td` = 0 #> • `astronomical_solution` = "full-ZB18a" #> • `os_ref_frame` = "HCI" #> • `os_omt` = defaulting to 75.594 #> • `os_inct` = defaulting to 7.155 #> • `tres` = -0.4 kyr #> • `atol` = 1e-05 #> • `rtol` = 0 #> • `solver` = "vode" #> ℹ started at "2024-03-04 13:39:55.132105" #> Final values: #> • s[1][2][3]: 0.404184487124565, -0.0537555129057148, and 0.913036138471423 #> • s-error = |s|-1: -5.51290422495798e-05 #> Final values: #> • obliquity: 0.413060472710089 rad #> • precession: -0.562357122261026 rad #> ℹ stopped at "2024-03-04 13:40:00.516361" #> ℹ total duration: 5.38s library(ggplot2) solution |>   ggplot(aes(x = time, y = cp)) +   labs(x = "Time (kyr)", y = "(-)", colour = "Orbital Element") +   # plot climatic precession   geom_line(aes(colour = "Climatic Precession")) +   # add the eccentricity envelope   geom_line(aes(y = ee, colour = "Eccentricity"),             data = get_solution() |> dplyr::filter(time > -1000)) +   scale_color_discrete(type = c("skyblue", "black")) +   theme(legend.position.inside = c(.9, .95))

title: Full Astronomical Solution ZB18a for the past 100 Myr — full_ZB18a
text: data frame 250,001 rows 20 columns: t Time \(t\) (days). time Time thousands years (kyr). aa Semimajor axis \(\) astronomical units (au). ee Eccentricity \(e\) (unitless). inc Inclination \(\) (degrees). lph Longitude perihelion \(\varpi\) (degrees). lan Longitude ascending node \(\Omega\) (degrees). arp Argument perihelion \(\omega\) (degrees). mna Mean anomaly \(M\) (degrees). lphu Unwrapped longitude perihelion \(\varpi\) (degrees without jumps). lanu Unwrapped longitude ascending node \(\Omega\) (degrees without jumps). hh Variable: \(e\sin(\varpi)\). kk Variable: \(e\cos(\varpi)\). pp Variable: \(2\sin(0.5I)\sin(\Omega)\). qq Variable: \(2\sin(0.5I)\cos(\Omega)\). cc Helper: \(\cos()\). dd Helper: \(\cos()/2\). nnx, nny, nnz \(x\), \(y\), \(z\)-components Eart's orbit unit normal vector \(\vec{n}\), normal Earth's instantaneous orbital plane.

title: Get an Astronomical Solution — get_solution
text: Download supported astronomical solutions web store user's cache directory. next use function load data cache rather downloading . also provides wrapper astrochron::getLaskar() one supported solutions specified, converts output tibble. Note cache solutions locally, however.

title: Get an Astronomical Solution — get_solution
code: get_solution(   astronomical_solution = "full-ZB18a",   quiet = FALSE,   force = FALSE )

title: Get an Astronomical Solution — get_solution
text: astronomical_solution Character vector name desired solution. Defaults "full-ZB18a". quiet quiet? TRUE, hide info messages. FALSE (default) print info messages timing. force Force re-downloading results, even solution saved cache.

title: Prepare Astronomical Solution — prepare_solution
text: Calculates helper columns astronomical solution input.

title: Prepare Astronomical Solution — prepare_solution
Prepare Astronomical Solution — prepare_solution
text: data data frame following columns: t Time \(t\) (days). ee Eccentricity \(e\) (unitless). lph Longitude perihelion \(\varpi\) (degrees). lan Longitude ascending node \(\Omega\) (degrees). inc Inclination \(\) (degrees). easiest way get get_solution(). quiet quiet? TRUE, hide info messages. FALSE (default) print info messages timing.

title: Prepare Astronomical Solution — prepare_solution
text: tibble new columns added.

title: Prepare Astronomical Solution — prepare_solution
text: New columns include: lphu Unwrapped longitude perihelion \(\varpi\) (degrees without jumps). lanu Unwrapped longitude ascending node \(\Omega\) (degrees without jumps). hh Variable: \(e\sin(\varpi)\). kk Variable: \(e\cos(\varpi)\). pp Variable: \(2\sin(0.5I)\sin(\Omega)\). qq Variable: \(2\sin(0.5I)\cos(\Omega)\). cc Helper: \(\cos()\). dd Helper: \(\cos()/2\). nnx, nny, nnz \(x\), \(y\), \(z\)-components Earth's orbit unit normal vector \(\vec{n}\), normal Earth's instantaneous orbital plane.

what: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past — snvec
title: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past — snvec
text: snvec() computes climatic precession obliquity (tilt) astronomical solution () input input values dynamical ellipticity (\(E_{d}\)) tidal dissipation (\(T_{d}\)). solves set ordinary differential equations.

title: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past — snvec
code: snvec(   tend = -1000,   ed = 1,   td = 0,   astronomical_solution = "full-ZB18a",   os_ref_frame = "HCI",   os_omt = NULL,   os_inct = NULL,   tres = -0.4,   atol = 1e-05,   rtol = 0,   solver = "vode",   quiet = FALSE,   output = "nice" )

title: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past — snvec
text: tend Final timestep thousands years (kyr). Defaults -1000 kyr. ed Dynamical ellipticity \(E_{d}\), normalized modern. Defaults 1.0. td Tidal dissipation \(T_{d}\), normalized modern. Defaults 0.0. astronomical_solution Character vector name desired solution. Defaults "full-ZB18a". os_ref_frame Character vector reference frame astronomical solution. Either "HCI" heliocentric inertial reference frame "J2000" ecliptic J2000 reference frame. Defaults "HCI" HNBody output. os_omt Longitude ascending node solar equator relative ECLIPJ2000. os_inct Inclination solar equator relative ECLIPJ2000. tres Output timestep resolution thousands years (kyr). Defaults -0.4. determine sign, think 0 tend timestep tres. atol Numerical absolute tolerance passed deSolve::ode()'s atol. Defaults 1e-5. rtol Numerical relative tolerance passed deSolve::ode()'s rtol. Defaults 0. solver Character vector specifying method passed deSolve::ode()'s method. Defaults "vode" stiff problems variable timestep. quiet quiet? TRUE, hide info messages. FALSE (default) print info messages timing. output Character vector name desired output. One : "nice" (default) tibble columns time, eei, epl, phi, cp. "full" tibble computed interpolated columns. "ode" matrix output ODE solver.

title: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past — snvec
text: snvec() returns different output depending outputs argument. output = "nice" (default), returns tibble following columns: time Time thousands years (kyr). epl Calculated Obliquity \(\epsilon\) (radians). phi Calculated Precession \(\phi\) (radians) ECLIPJ2000. cp Calculated Climatic precession (-) \(e\sin\bar{\omega}\). \(\bar{\omega}\) longitude perihelion relative moving equinox. output = "" (developers), additional columns included, typically interpolated output timescale. sx, sy, sz \(x\), \(y\), \(z\)-components Earth's spin axis unit vector \(\vec{s}\) heliocentric inertial reference frame. See source code descriptions intermediate computational steps. output = "ode", return raw output ODE solver, object class deSolve matrix, columns time, sx, sy, sz. can useful .e. deSolve::diagnostics().

title: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past — snvec
text: re-implementation C-code supplementary information Zeebe & Lourens (2022). terms explained detail Zeebe (2022).

title: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past — snvec
text: NASA provides asteroid planet positions ecliptic J2000 reference frame, long-term astronomical solution integrations often performed heliocentric inertial reference frame (HCI) inertial reference frame. align reference frame spin vector Sun, making J2 corrections intuitive implement. Obliquity typically given ecliptic reference frame, snvec converts outputs J2000 os_ref_frame equal "HCI" transformations already "J2000". , uses \(\Omega_{\odot} = 75.5940\) \(i_{\odot} = 7.155\) Zeebe (2017). can overwrite defaults os_omt os_inct desired.

title: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past — snvec
text: Note different ODE solver algorithm use (Soetaert et al., 2010) means R routine returns evenly-spaced time grid, whereas C-routine variable time-step. means need explicitly set stepsize tres.

title: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past — snvec
text: Zeebe, R.E. (2017). Numerical Solutions Orbital Motion Solar System Past 100 Myr: Limits New Results. Astronomical Journal, 154(5), doi:10.3847/1538-3881/aa8cce . Zeebe, R. E., & Lourens, L. J. (2019). Solar System chaos Paleocene–Eocene boundary age constrained geology astronomy. Science, 365(6456), 926–929. doi:10.1126/science.aax0612 . Zeebe, R. E., & Lourens, L. J. (2022). deep-time dating tool paleo-applications utilizing obliquity precession cycles: role dynamical ellipticity tidal dissipation. Paleoceanography Paleoclimatology, e2021PA004349. doi:10.1029/2021PA004349 . Zeebe, R. E. (2022). Reduced Variations Earth’s Mars’ Orbital Inclination Earth’s Obliquity 58 48 Myr ago due Solar System Chaos. Astronomical Journal, 164(3), doi:10.3847/1538-3881/ac80f8 . Wikipedia page Orbital Elements: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_elements Karline Soetaert, Thomas Petzoldt, R. Woodrow Setzer (2010). Solving Differential Equations R: Package deSolve. Journal Statistical Software, 33(9), 1–25. doi:10.18637/jss.v033.i09 .

title: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past — snvec
code: # \donttest{ # default call snvec() #> This is snvecR VERSION: 3.9.1 2024-03-04 #> Richard E. Zeebe #> Ilja J. Kocken #>  #> Integration parameters: #> • `tend` = -1000 kyr #> • `ed` = 1 #> • `td` = 0 #> • `astronomical_solution` = "full-ZB18a" #> • `os_ref_frame` = "HCI" #> • `os_omt` = defaulting to 75.594 #> • `os_inct` = defaulting to 7.155 #> • `tres` = -0.4 kyr #> • `atol` = 1e-05 #> • `rtol` = 0 #> • `solver` = "vode" #> ℹ started at "2024-03-05 11:33:36.383027" #> Final values: #> • s[1][2][3]: 0.404184487124565, -0.0537555129057148, and 0.913036138471423 #> • s-error = |s|-1: -5.51290422495798e-05 #> Final values: #> • obliquity: 0.413060472710089 rad #> • precession: -0.562357122261026 rad #> ℹ stopped at "2024-03-05 11:33:40.510676" #> ℹ total duration: 4.13s #> # A tibble: 2,501 × 4 #>     time   epl    phi     cp #>    <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1   0   0.409 0      0.0163 #>  2  -0.4 0.410 0.0975 0.0168 #>  3  -0.8 0.411 0.195  0.0171 #>  4  -1.2 0.412 0.292  0.0170 #>  5  -1.6 0.413 0.389  0.0168 #>  6  -2   0.414 0.486  0.0163 #>  7  -2.4 0.414 0.582  0.0156 #>  8  -2.8 0.415 0.679  0.0146 #>  9  -3.2 0.416 0.775  0.0134 #> 10  -3.6 0.417 0.871  0.0120 #> # ℹ 2,491 more rows  # ignore the below, this is just to make CRAN builds happy! # remove the directory with the cached astronomical solution to clean up unlink(snvecR:::cachedir, recursive = TRUE) # }

what: snvecR: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past — snvecR-package
title: snvecR: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past — snvecR-package
text: Easily calculate precession obliquity orbital solution (defaults ZB18a Zeebe Lourens (2019) doi:10.1126/science.aax0612 ) assumed reconstructed values tidal dissipation (Td) dynamical ellipticity (Ed). translation adaptation C-code supplementary material Zeebe Lourens (2022) doi:10.1029/2021PA004349 , details methodology described Zeebe (2022) doi:10.3847/1538-3881/ac80f8 . name C-routine snvec, refers key units computation: spin vector s orbit normal vector n.

title: snvecR: Calculate Earth’s Obliquity and Precession in the Past — snvecR-package
text: Maintainer: Ilja Kocken ikocken@hawaii.edu (ORCID) [translator, copyright holder] Authors: Richard Zeebe zeebe@soest.hawaii.edu (ORCID)

title: Tidy eval helpers — tidyeval
text: page lists tidy eval tools reexported package rlang. learn using tidy eval scripts packages high level, see dplyr programming vignette ggplot2 packages vignette. Metaprogramming section Advanced R may also useful deeper dive. .data pronoun object represents current slice data. variable name string, use .data pronoun subset variable [[.

title: snvecR 3.9.1
text: CRAN release: 2024-03-04

title: snvecR 3.9.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-03-01 Refactor age ka time kyr throughout. Rename default astronomical solution PT-ZB18a full-ZB18a. OS, convert time negative consistency. Changed default output! Now returns time (kyr), longer t t_kyr.

title: snvecR 3.8.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-01-26 Fix snapshot tests CI (overwrite cache dir, unique test). Make possible user specify custom orbital solution data.frame. either column names output get_ZB18a() output orbitN; automatically convert column names snvec columns names convenience. Rename orbital solution astronomical solution throughout. Migrate get_ZB18a get_ZB user can easily get Zeebe solutions website (cache well). Added support reading Zeebe astronomical solutions function get_solution(). Also added wrapper astrochron::getLaskar() user provides supported Laskar solution name.

title: snvecR 3.7.7
text: CRAN release: 2023-06-09 Fix CRAN issues revising logic checking cache.

title: snvecR 3.7.6
text: CRAN release: 2023-05-31 Remove cache directory last example (even though ’s donttest environment).

title: snvecR 3.7.5
text: CRAN release: 2023-05-19 Added NEWS.md file track changes package. Note: version number consistent snvec C package. Implemented first public version based C-code Zeebe Lourens 2022, explained . Added snvec() function work. Added ZB18a dataset orbital solution. Added tests using testthat. Added snvec() output parameter choice select "ode", "", "nice" (default). Added vignette grid variations Td Ed. Added bookdown website rendering. Released version Zenodo assigned doi. Removed ZB18a dataset package large. Added functions get_solution, get_ZB18a, prepare_solution. Added caching code orbital solution. Remove cache directory running tests, reproducible environments remain clean.
